title: Bailiwick of Jersey (obverse)
subject: Monarch
description: Depicts sculptor, artist, coin and stamp designer, Arnold Machin's, 1969 portrait of Queen Elizabeth II. It was used for British coins until 1984.
creator: Arnold Machin
rights: Copyright protected material may be reproduced free of charge in any format or medium for research, private study or for internal circulation within an organisation.

title: Bailiwick of Jersey (reverse)
subject: Location
description: Depicts the arch of the Grosnez Castle Ruins, built in 1330. Bailiwick of Jersey is, a British Crown Dependency, made up of small islands in the English Channel. Bailiwick of Jersey and Bailiwick of Guernsey make up the Channel Islands. It is not officially part of the United Kingdom, but follows similar systems, akin to the relationship between the United States of America and its territories. Interestingly, this coin is not legal tender in the United Kingdom, however due to the similar shape and weight of the coin to British 50p coins it isn't easily recognizable as foreign currency.
creator: George Edward Kruger-Gray

title: The 250th Anniversary of Samuel Johnson's Dictionary of the English Language (reverse)
subject: Historical Event;Cultural Contribution
description: Depicts a dictionary-esque entry on "pence" with Saxon script to celebrate the 250th anniversary of Samuel Johnson's Johnson's Dictionary also known as A Dictionary of the English Language, published on April 15, 1755. It is one of the most influential English dictionaries in history and took Johnson seven years to finish. He completed the work by himself, in addition to publishing multiple revised versions.

title: The 150th Anniversary of the Institution of the Victoria Cross (reverse)
subject: Historical Event;Cultural Contribution
description: Depicts the anniversary of the creation of the Victoria Cross. The VC is the highest decoration in the British military awards system. It was first introduced in 1856 by Queen Victoria for heroic acts in the Crimean War. The first recipient was Charles Davis Lucas on June 26, 1857, and the most recent recipient was Joshua Leakey in 2013. This award was groundbreaking, as it was created in part to keep pace with other European countries that gave awards regardless of social class or rank. This award was created to honor acts of gallantry, irrespective of length or merit of service. More than a century and a half after its creation it remains significant, representing true patriotism.

title: Celebrating 100 Years of Girlguiding UK (reverse)
subject: Historical Event;Cultural Contribution
description: Depicts a design composed of three-leaf clovers, the symbol of Girlguiding, the Guide Association, previously known as The Girl Guides Association, to celebrate the centennary. The assocation was founded in 1910, but the celebrations were held over three years (2010-2012) all over the world, commencing with a maze at Crystal Palace noting the 1909 Crystal Palace Scout Rally which demonstrated the rising popularity of Scouting. At the rally, girl scouts called for their own organization, prompting the Girl Guides organization founding the following year. Girl Guides are made up of Rainbows, Brownies, Guides and Rangers. The organization has a close association with the Royal Family, wich Princess Mary, Queen Elizabeth II, and Princess Margaret having been among their ranks.

title: London 2012 - Table Tennis (reverse)
subject: Historical Event
description: Depicts a design celebrating Table Tennis, one of the 26 different sports that made up the programme at the London 2012 Summer Olympic Games. Table Tennis first appeared as part of the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. The Royal Mint issued 29 coins for the event depicting various sports in the Summer Olympic and Paraolympic Games. The coins were released in the 2011, with the exception of the "Athletics" coin in 2009. The 2012 Games marked the third time London hosted, the first city to do so. The United States topped the charts with a total of 104 medals, 48 gold, 26 silver, and 30 bronze.

title: The Glasgow 2014 Commonwealth Games (reverse)
subject: Historical Event
description: Depicts a cycler, a runner, and two x's for the 2014 Commonwealth Games which were held in Glasgow, also known as the XX Commonwealth Games. The Commonwealth Games are a quadrennial international sporting competition between the Commonwealth Nations, first held in 1930, and inspired by the Inter-Empire Championships in 1911. In 2018, it became the first global multi-sport event to have an even number of women's and men's medal events. The Games marked the largest multi-sport event ever to be held in Scotland. England topped the chart with a total of 174 medals, 58 gold, 59 silver and 57 bronze.

title: The 150th Anniversary of the Birth of Beatrix Potter (reverse)
subject: Cultural Contribution
description: Depicts a profile portrait of Beatrix Potter, with her birth and death dates, and a portrait of Peter Rabbit, her most well-known creation. She produced 23 Tales and 12 other books. Apart from being a children's book author, Potter was also an illustrator, natrual scientist and conservationist. Her likeness and works have been adapted for stage and screen, and she left much of her estate to the National Trust.

title: Beatrix Potter - The Tale of Peter Rabbit (reverse)
subject: Pop Culture
description: Depicts a portrait of Beatrix Potter's most beloved character, Peter Rabbit, who first appeared in The Tale of Peter Rabbit, published in 1901. He is a mischievous young rabbit who lives with his mother and sisters, Flopsy, Mopsy and Cotton-Tail. He ventures into Mr. McGregor's garden looking for vegetables and gets chased out. His character has been adapted for stage and screen. He appears most recently in the 2021 feature film, a sequel to Peter Rabbit, released in 2018.

title: Beatrix Potter - Tom Kitten (reverse)
subject: Pop Culture
description: Depicts a portrait of Beatrix Potter's character, Tom Kitten, who first appears in The Tale of Tom Kitten, published in 1907. Tom's mother, Tabitha Twitchit, invites her friends for tea, but Tom, along with his siblings, Mittens and Moppet get into trouble. They play in the garden beforehand and ruin their clothes. The book was inteded to teach children about manners. This cat family later appear in other Tales, and have been adapted for animation.

title: Beatrix Potter - Mr. Jeremy Fisher (reverse)
subject: Pop Culture
description: Depicts a portrait of Beatrix Potter's character Mr. Jeremy Fisher. He is a frog who is intent on fishing to catch dinner for his dinner party. He first appears in The Tale of Mr. Jeremy Fisher, published in 1906. He has a challenging fishing adventure, where he gets pricked by a stickleback fish and almost swallowed by a trout. He ends up serving grassphopper and ladybird sauce. His likeness has been adapted for stage and screen.

title: Beatrix Potter - Benjamin Bunny (reverse)
subject: Pop Culture
description: Depicts a portrait of Beatrix Potter's character, Benajmin Bunny, who first appears in The Tale of Benjamin Bunny in 1904. His Tale is a sequel to The Tale of Peter Rabbit, where Peter, Benjamin's cousin, has gone back to Mr. McGregor's garden in hopes of retriving his lost clothes. He appears in The Tale of Mrs. Tiggy-Winkle as well as in The Tale of the Flopsy Bunnies and The tale of Mr. Tod. His likeness has been adapted for stage and screen.

title: Isle of Man Sapphire Jubilee - The Imperial State Crown (reverse)
subject: Historical Event
description: Depicts the St Edwards Crown, which is the centerpiece of the Crown Jewels, made in 1661, to celebrate the, Sapphire Jubilee/65th Anniversary of the Crowning of Queen Elizabeth II. She was the first monarch to have a Sapphire Jubilee, and subsequently celebrated her Platinum Jubilee/70th Anniversary of her Coronation in 2022. Her Sapphire celebration did not have any offical engagments or large public celbration. She was the longest reigning monarch in British History.

title: The 100th Anniversary of the Passing of the Representation of the People Act 1918 (reverse)
subject: Historical Event
description: Depicts women and young men holding up ballots, as it celebrates the centennary of the passing of the Representation of the People Act in 1918. This act granted the right to vote to men over 21, regardless of whether they owned property, and wome over the age of 30 who occupied property valuing over £5 or whose husbands did. It also allowed women over 30 to particpate in local government franchise. Unfortunately, women didn't receive electoral equity until 1928, when any woman over 21 was able to vote.

title: Paddington at the Station (reverse)
subject: Pop Culture
description: Depicts an image of Paddington Bear perched on his suitcase in Paddington station. Knapton's design appears to be based off the 2014 film Paddington's character, as he bears a sharper resemblance to the film's bear than the original book illustrations. Additionally, the train station has modern trains, rather than those of 1958, when Paddington first appeared in the children's book, A Bear Called Paddington by Michael Bond, the first of over 20. Paddington's inpsiration came from a teddy bear in a shop and refugee children from WWII. The character has been adapted for telvision and film, with the most recent films being nomianted for BAFTA awards.

title: Sherlock Holmes (reverse)
subject: Pop Culture
description: Depicts an image of Sherlock Holmes' profile with his signature deer stalker hat and pipe, surrounded by the titles of his most famous adventures. Sherlock Holmes first appeared as a consulting detective in 1887 in Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's A Study in Scarlet. There are four novels and 56 short stories about Sherlock Holmes, and the Guinness World Records states that his character is the most portrayed human literary character in film and television history.
